newsitem.title: USA: Progress made in tobacco talks says New York Times.
newsitem.headline: Progress made in tobacco talks says New York Times.

text.p: Negotiators in the tobacco talks are making progress on several key regulatory and legal issues, but many hurdles remain the New York Times said in its Friday edition.

The tobacco industry is facing a wave of civil claims from smokers and their families for the damage done to their health, and claims from U.S. state seeking to recoup public medical costs for treating smokers.

The talks are aimed at reaching an out of court settlement which will give tobacco companies at least partial immunity from future smoking-related claims in exchange for paying billions of dollars into a compensation fund.

Quoting unnamed sources close to the talks, the Times said one area of agreement reached by negotiators involves a substantial penalty that cigarette makers would pay if smoking by young people is not reduced by 50 percent after seven years.

Still unresolved, however, is the issue of the size of any settlement fund to compensate ill smokers, their survivors and the 29 states that have sued the tobacco industry to recover Medicaid money spent on smoking-related claims, the Times said.
"We feel that we have made good progress," Mississippi Attorney General Michael Moore told the Times. Moore is a principal architect of the talks.
